newsitem.title: EGYPT: Egypt shares set new record despite profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Egypt shares set new record despite profit-taking.

text.p: Egyptian shares rose on Wednesday to their highest level in about two years despite what brokers said was as a quiet market marked profit-taking.
The Capital Market Authority (CMA) overall index rose 0.49 points to 239.52 points, its highest level since early December 1994. Volume reached 60.03 million pounds ($17.66 million).
"The market is still quiet," said broker Youssef Khalil of Delta EAB. "But this is usual with profit-taking dealings after recent increases."
Telemisr/Arab Radio Transistor and Electronics Supplies was the day's biggest gainer after recent losses. The share rose 2.02 pounds, or 7.35 percent, closing at 29.53 pounds.

"There are rumours in the market about a close agreement between Telemisr and Japan's NEC to allow the Japanese firm to buy an anchor investor stake in Telemisr," Hany el-Sayyed of el-Rashad Securities Brokerage.
Central and West Delta Flour Mills was the day's most active share rising 0.99 pounds to close at 58.25. Shares worth 1.02 million pounds changed hands.
"The millers are generally on a selling trend after their good performance recently," Khalil said.
The cement sector, another favourite sector, dominated the market.
Suez Cement was the second most active share. Shares worth 789,747 pounds were traded, but ended down 0.25 pounds to 48.70.
Egyptian Tora Portland Cement shed 0.05 pounds to close at 62.26 pounds. Alexandria Portland Cement added 5.00 pounds to finish at 485.00.
The CMA index for openly traded firms rose to 359.47 points from 358.79 on Tuesday and the index for rarely traded "closed" firms rose to 168.66 from 168.29 points.
Advances outnumbered declines 18 to 16, while 30 shares ended unchanged.
